title: How to spend a night in the opera
text:
Patrick Lau Aug 29, 2019 — 12.11pm Share

Anyone who’s noticed that enormous building down by Sydney Harbour knows that opera has a special place in Australians’ hearts. Homegrown soprano Dame Nellie Melba even holds top billing on our $100 note.

Now, lovers of the form can tread the boards themselves, as Opera Australia’s walk-on offer is providing a novel way to get among the action.

The package costs $5000 and just 10 spots are available each year, and only during specific productions – this year, it was La Boheme. The walk-on participant is taken through a fitting, costuming and make-up, getting something of the everyday experience of a performer. Don’t bother warming up your pipes, though; walk-ons don’t get to sing.

It’s perhaps a sign of how beloved Opera Australia is that its programming is always controversial, yet invariably successful. Last year, artistic director Lyndon Terracini announced that OA was “the only opera company in the world where more than 50 per cent of our budget comes from box office, because we’ve embraced the 21st century”.

Part of this, he says, is introducing experiences such as the walk-on roles. “Walk-on roles are fantastic for people who usually sit in the audience,” he says, adding that they offer a new perspective on the production. And despite the attendant panic that may come from having newcomers on the stage each night, Terracini is adamant that the experience is “virtually risk-free”.

Terracini is known for programming plenty of crowd-pleasing fare, including evergreens with well-known arias and big choral pieces, such as La Boheme, Turandot and Carmen. This year’s Sydney Harbour spectacle was West Side Story; the Romeo and Juliet romance set to a poppy Bernstein score.

But under Terracini, Opera Australia has also been feted for work that defies expectations. The 2019 season included a new digital opera about Brett Whiteley and a difficult production of the atonal Wozzeck. And for those who can’t get enough Valkyries, in 2020 the company will present Wagner’s Ring Cycle in its entirety, clocking in at 15 hours spread over four nights.

description: For a cool $5000, musical drama fans now have the chance to join the action on stage.
